chapter: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false regarding the surgical anatomy of the kidney?

options.a: The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery
options.b: The line of Brodel is an important access route for renal surgeries
options.c: The renal arteries are end arteries without collateral circulation
options.d: The kidney has a very poor lymphatic network

questions.explanation:
The kidney has an extensive lymphatic network. It begins in three plexuses which drain into the lateral aortic nodes. These are located around the 
renal tubules, under the renal capsule, and in the perirenal fat. The renal arteries are end arteries without collateral circulation. The right renal artery is longer 
than the left renal artery. This is due to the position of the abdominal aorta which is slightly to the 877 
Sold by @itachibot left of the midline. The left renal vein is much longer than the right renal vein. This is due to the position of the IVC 
which is slightly to the right of the midline. The line of Brodel is the avascular plane of the kidney. It lies between anterior and posterior 
segmental branches. It is an important access route for both open and endoscopic surgical 
procedures, as it minimizes the risk of damage to major arterial branches.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is true concerning a live-donor kidney transplant?

options.a: The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site
options.b: The renal artery is anastomosed end-to-end to the external iliac artery
options.c: The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the internal iliac vein
options.d: Right kidney is preferred over the left for transplantation

questions.explanation:
The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site chosen for transplantation of the 
kidney. The left kidney is preferred for transplantation because the left renal vein is longer. In the case of a deceased donor, the arterial graft is traced until the aorta which makes it longer, 
and hence end-to-side anastomosis is possible. Whereas, in the case of a live donor, the arterial 
graft cannot be extended until the aorta. The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live and 
deceased donors. Live donor 
Deceased donor Anastomosis

questions.question:
Question 3: An intravenous pyelogram done for evaluation of recurrent UTI in a child is shown below. 
Which of the following is false regarding this condition? 868 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Associated with an increased incidence of renal cell carcinoma
options.c: Lies just below the origin of inferior mesenteric artery
options.d: Division at the level of the isthmus improves function

questions.explanation:
The given scenario with intravenous pyelogram showing flower vase sign points to a diagnosis of 
horseshoe kidney. Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is usually not 
indicated. This is because it can lead to an increased risk of urinary fistula. Horseshoe kidneys are the most common fusion defects of the kidney, characterized by 
abnormalities in the position, rotation, and vascular supply of the kidney. The fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior 
mesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery. 
Adrenal glands remain in the normal position. There is a 2:1 male predominance. It is also commonly associated with renal cell carcinoma, 
Wilms tumor, multicystic dysplastic kidney, and Turner’s syndrome. Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with: • Dull renal pain • Abdominal lump • Urinary tract infections • Increased angulation of ureters resulting in - • Nephrolithiasis • Hydronephrosis Radiological diagnosis is by intravenous pyelogram which shows flower vase sign or handshake 
sign. Symptomatic management is preferred. Heminephrectomy is usually not indicated for horseshoe 
kidneys with unilateral RCC/ Wilms tumor. This is because it can result in devascularisation due 
to the unpredictable blood supply of the horseshoe kidney from nearby major vessels. 879 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is only indicated in the 
course of surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm. The below CECT shows a fusion defect of the kidneys.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 4: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed a 
dilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of 
a duplex kidney. It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete 
fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal 
systems draining single renal parenchyma. 880 
Sold by @itachibot The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an 
ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of 
insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence. Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. 
Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 5: A known hypertensive presented with intermittent left-sided flank pain. His brother passed 
away two years ago due to a ruptured berry aneurysm. CT abdomen done is shown below. 
Which of the following is false regarding his condition? 869 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Decompression of cyst improves renal function

questions.explanation:
The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis of 
adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). In such patients, decompression or deroofing of the 
cysts (Rovsing’s procedure) cannot restore normal renal function. ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) 
and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never 
diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males. Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include: • Flank/loin pain - either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly 
uric acid stones) • Irregular upper quadrant renal mass • Hematuria • Uremia • Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis) Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due 
to multiple cysts. Nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence 
of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. 881 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment includes: • Long-term dialysis • Renal transplantation • Vasopressin V2 receptor antagonists Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) occurs secondary to a mutation of the 
PKHD1 gene. The severe form manifests in-utero or during infancy; milder cases can manifest 
later in childhood. 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 6: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What 
is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junction 
points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis. Hydronephrosis refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or complete 
blockage of urinary flow. Investigations: • Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis. • Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction before 
corrective surgery. • Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, the 
extrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, there 
is blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages. • A renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation 
of the collecting system.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 7: An ultrasound scan done at 32 weeks for a woman with oligohydramnios revealed fetal 
hydronephrosis. What is the most likely cause for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of hydronephrosis found on 
prenatal ultrasound. The causes of UPJ obstruction can be: • Intrinsic - due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter • Extrinsic - due to accessory renal arteries Treatment includes Anderson Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty. Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis. In 
VUR, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective. Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from the 
persistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. IVU shows cobra 
head/ adder head appearance. 882 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as a 
result of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet 
obstruction in male newborns. Note: Renal stones are the most common cause of acquired unilateral hydronephrosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 8: A mother brings her 3-month-old infant to the OPD with complaints of him crying while 
urinating. On palpation, a left-sided flank mass is felt. A USG KUB revealed dilation of the 
pelvicalyceal system with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the investigation of 
choice to confirm his diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of a ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction. The investigation of 
choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Delayed clearance 
of contrast or the radiotracer implies obstruction. Renal isotope scans have replaced intravenous pyelogram as the diagnostic modality of choice in 
UPJ obstruction. • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the 
tubular function. • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function. Hence, it is 
commonly used to assess GFR. In obstructive uropathy, 99mTc-DTPA is the preferred isotope as glomerular function declines 
earlier and more rapidly than tubular function. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. Tc-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring. Note: In children, crying before and after micturition is usually considered normal. While crying 
during micturition is usually suggestive of pathology.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 9: A child was brought to you with recurrent episodes of colicky abdominal pain. USG revealed 
left-sided hydronephrosis. On the third follow-up day, a decrease in abdominal pain was 
noted after he passed a large amount of urine. Repeat USG showed a significant decrease in 
the size of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of hydronephrosis with renal pain relieved after the passage of a large amount 
of urine is suggestive of Dietl's crisis. It is defined as intermittent ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction causing episodic abdominal 
pain and nausea, most often due to an aberrant accessory renal artery or vein. In an acute phase of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, loin swelling occurs along with 
renal pain due to the retention of urine in the kidney. When the obstruction is relieved, the 
patient passes a large amount of urine, the swelling is reduced and the pain disappears. This is 
termed Dietl's crisis. In the majority of cases, pyeloplasty results in the complete resolution of symptoms.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following are risk factors for calcium stone formation?
questions.explanation:
Hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and hyperuricosuria are risk factors for calcium stone formation. 883 
Sold by @itachibot Risk factors for calcium stone formation include: • High urine concentration of calcium, oxalate, or uric acid • Low urine concentration of renal stone inhibiting factors such as citrate and magnesium • Abnormal urine pH Renal stone formation is governed by factors promoting and inhibiting stone formation. Stone 
formation occurs when the concentration product is more than the formation product i.e., CP > 
FP, where: • Concentration product (CP) - the amount of solute in solution • Formation product (FP) - maximum concentration of solute in solution after taking into account 
stone inhibiting factors.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 11: Which among the following is the investigation of choice in a patient suspected to have 
ureteric stones?
questions.explanation:
Non-contrast CT abdomen (NCCT) is the investigation of choice for the clinical evaluation of 
ureteric stones. NCCT is the preferred investigation for evaluation of: • Renal stones except for indinavir stones • Ureteric stones • Head injury • Salivary gland stones
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 12: A man presents to the casualty with fever and hematuria for 3 days. He also gives a history of 
recurrent left-sided loin pain radiating to the groin. X-ray KUB done is shown below. Which 
of the following is false regarding stones seen in his condition? 872 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Composed of calcium, ammonium, and magnesium phosphate
options.b: It is formed in acidic urine
options.c: Increased risk with infections by urease producing organisms
options.d: Rectangular or coffin lid appearance on microscopy

questions.explanation:
The given scenario and X-Ray KUB showing staghorn appearance points to a diagnosis of struvite 
stones. Struvite stone is produced in alkaline urine. It is commonly associated with infections with urea-splitting organisms like Proteus and 
Klebsiella species. Increased metabolism of urea results in alkalinity of the urine. Struvite is a triple-phosphate calculus (calcium, ammonium, and magnesium phosphate). The 
calculus may enlarge to fill most of the collecting system, forming a staghorn calculus. These stones are dirty-white in color, and grossly smooth in texture. Rectangular or coffin 
lid appearance is seen on microscopic examination.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 13: Acetohydroxamic acid will be prescribed for patients with which of the following types of 
renal stones?
questions.explanation:
Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone. 884 
Sold by @itachibot It is a urease inhibitor. The urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the 
urine. This favors the production of struvite stones. Thus, the use of AHA(Acetohydroxamic acid) 
causes complete, noncompetitive inhibition of urease production, thereby slowing struvite stone 
growth. Owing to its side-effects, the use of this drug has been restricted in cases of recurrent 
UTIs, and those intolerant or who refuse surgical management. It can also be used for oral chemolysis and can potentiate the action of antibiotics.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient is referred for the evaluation of severe right-sided abdominal pain. Abdominal X-ray 
appears normal, and a USG revealed the presence of a 6mm renal stone. Which of the 
following stones is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario since the stone is radiolucent, it is most likely to be uric acid stone. Uric acid stones are preferentially formed in acidic urine. It is commonly associated with 
disorders of purine metabolism such as gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. On microscopic 
examination, the crystals appear as glass shards. Patients with recurrent uric acid stones are treated with Allopurinol. Note: 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque, while 80% of gall bladder stones are radiolucent.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 15: The urine microscopy of a young man admitted for the evaluation of renal stones shows the 
following finding. What type of stone is this? 873 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The urine microscopy shows the presence of hexagonal-shaped stones which are likely to be 
cystine stones. These stones are commonly found in acidic urine. Recurrent stones are treated using 
D-penicillamine.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements is false regarding renal stones?

options.a: A low calcium diet can prevent the recurrence of calcium stone
options.b: Potassium citrate reduces the risk of uric acid stone
options.c: d-Penicillamine can be used to prevent cystine stone formation
options.d: Pyridoxine can reduce the risk of oxalate stone formation

questions.explanation:
A low calcium diet has not shown any significant benefit in the prevention of calcium stone 
formation, compared to a normocalcemic diet. However, a diet rich in calcium rather binds with dietary oxalate and reduces dietary absorption 
of oxalate. This effect leads to a lower risk of calcium oxalate stone formation in the kidneys. Option B: Uric acid crystallization and stone formation take place in acidic pH. Therefore, urinary 
alkalinization by potassium citrate reduces the risk of urate stone formation. Option C: Cystine stones are usually formed in presence of cystinuria. Initial treatment options to 
prevent recurrent cystine stone formation includes increased fluid intake and urinary 
alkalinization (e.g citrate). If this therapy fails, d-penicillamine can be used. Option D: Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor in the oxalic acid metabolism process and helps in the 
reduction of endogenous oxalate levels. Several studies have mentioned the role of pyridoxine in 
the reduction of oxalate stone formation. 885 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 17: An HIV-positive man on HAART presents to the casualty with intermittent right-sided flank 
pain. He is suspected to have renal stones. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be 
responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Indinavir (a protease-inhibitor) is most likely to be responsible for renal stones in a patient on 
HAART. It has the highest incidence of nephrolithiasis among anti-retroviral drugs. Indinavir is released in high concentration in the urine due to poor solubility in the physiologic 
pH. Consequently, patients develop stones that are principally composed of indinavir or of a 
mixture of indinavir and other substances, such as calcium oxalate. Other urolithogenic drugs are: • Antihypertensives - furosemide, bumetanide (loop diuretics), triamterene (potassium-sparing 
diuretic) • Decongestant - ephedrine • Expectorant - guaifenesin • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - acetazolamide, topiramate, and zonisamide • Newer antiretroviral agents - lopinavir-ritonavir, ritonavir-boosted atazanavir, nelfinavir, and 
amprenavir
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse?
questions.explanation:
Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse. Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the 
production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia 
and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and 
ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones. These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent 
urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation. The below image shows an ammonium urate stone. 886 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 19: A woman with severe right-sided colicky loin pain is suspected to have renal calculi. What is 
the maximum size of the calculi up to which this patient can be managed expectantly?
questions.explanation:
Patients with renal calculi  0.5 cm in size can be treated expectantly, as they are likely to pass 
spontaneously. Medical management of renal stones involves: • Pain control with NSAIDs or opioid analgesics • Medical expulsive therapy with tamsulosin ( blocker) and Nifedipine (calcium channel blockers) • Monitoring for the symptoms of urinary tract infection and decreased renal function
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 20: In patients with which of the following renal stones, will extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy 
not be considered?
questions.explanation:
Cystine stones are very hard stones, hence it is difficult to disintegrate it with extracorporeal 
shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL). ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused 
on the stones. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Stones that are difficult to disintegrate by ESWL: • Cystine • Brushite • Calcium oxalate monohydrate Stones that are relatively easy to disintegrate by ESWL: • Calcium oxalate dihydrate • Phosphate
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 21: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy is contraindicated in all of the following patients 
except?

options.a: A young woman with untreated bleeding diathesis
options.c: A man with a ureteric stricture
options.d: A middle aged man with a saccular aneurysm

questions.explanation:
Saccular aneurysm or berry aneurysm is not a contraindication for extracorporeal shockwave 
lithotripsy (ESWL). Contraindications to ESWL: • Pregnancy • Uncorrected coagulopathy or bleeding diathesis • Untreated urinary tract infection • Arterial aneurysm near stones (renal or abdominal aortic aneurysms) • Obstruction of urinary tract distal to the stones 887 
Sold by @itachibot • Skeletal malformations resulting in an inability to target stones Complications of ESWL include: • Pain • Hematuria • Steinstrasse - means a street of stones. It occurs due to the collection of stone fragments in the 
ureter • Urinary tract infections
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 22: An elderly woman was brought to the hospital with a history of severe loin pain for the past 7 
hours. Ultrasound of the kidney reveals a 2.5 cm renal stone. What is the treatment of choice 
for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size >2cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy 
(PCNL). In PCNL, endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique, and 
stones are removed. PCNL is also indicated in: • Staghorn calculi • Multiple stones • Proximal ureteral stones >1 cm Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include hemorrhage, perforation of the collecting 
system, and of the colon or pleural cavity. Another approach for the management of renal stones is ureteroscopic removal(URS) 
or retrograde intra-renal surgery (RIRS). In URS, stones are removed via a retrograde approach 
using a dormia basket, or a Holmium YAG laser is used to break the stones. If PCNL or URS fails, open or laparoscopic pyelolithotomy or nephrolithotomy is done. The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy. 888 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 23: A man came to the casualty with right-sided colicky loin pain radiating to the inner thigh. 
NCCT abdomen revealed a non-impacted 1cm calculi in the right ureter. How will you 
manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ureteroscopic removal is the preferred treatment in non-impacted ureteric stones >5-6mm in 
size.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question:
Question 24: A man was brought to the casualty with severe left-sided colicky flank pain. On examination, 
he was febrile, with a BP of 90/60 mmHg and a feeble rapid pulse. Investigations revealed 
WBC= 16,800 with a 2.5 cm calculi in the left ureter. What is the preferred management in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of a patient in sepsis secondary to an obstructed renal calculi. 
Nephrostomy is the preferred management in these patients. Treatment in patients with sepsis secondary to an obstructing urinary tract calculi includes: • Insertion of a percutaneous nephrostomy • Insertion of a ureteric stent via cystoscopy Nephrostomy is preferred in extremely unwell patients as it is less manipulative and has a lower 
risk of septicemia. 889 
Sold by @itachibot Infections and Tumors of Kidney
